column1: A bone scan is an imaging test used to diagnose bone diseases and find out how severe they are.
The camera takes pictures of how much radiotracer collects in the bones.
If a bone scan is done to see if you have a bone infection, images may be taken shortly after the radioactive material is injected and again 3 to 4 hours later, when it has collected in the bones.
You must remove jewelry and other metal objects.
A bone scan is used to: - Diagnose a bone tumor or cancer - Determine if a cancer that began elsewhere in your body has spread to the bones.

- Diagnose a fracture, when it cannot be seen on a regular x-ray (most commonly hip fractures, stress fractures in the feet or legs, or spine fractures) - Diagnose a bone infection (osteomyelitis) - Diagnose or determine the cause of bone pain, when no other cause has been identified - Evaluate metabolic disorders, such as osteomalacia, primary hyperparathyroidism, osteoporosis, complex regional pain syndrome, and Paget disease
An abnormal scan will show "hot spots" and/or "cold spots" as compared to surrounding bone.
